code: @Manual{,   title = {algebraic.mle: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators},   author = {Alexander Towell},   year = {2022},   note = {https://github.com/queelius/algebraic.mle, https://queelius.github.io/algebraic.mle/}, }

title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: algebra maximum likelihood estimators (MLE). MLEs many desirable, well-defined statistical properties. define algebra MLEs.

title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: can install development version algebraic.mle GitHub :

what: MLE of rate parameter in exponential distribution
title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: follows, demonstrate algebraic.mle R package, consider random sample exponentially distributed random variable Xi ∼ EXP (λ=1)  = 1, …, n. generate observation random sample : observed sample size n = 1000. show observations sample (data frame) : show histogram sample, plot exponential function’s pdf, :  like estimate λ, can using maximum likelihood estimation implemented algebraic.mle package: can show point estimator : can show Fisher information variance-covariance matrices : (rate.hat vector, vcov output variance-covariance matrix. may consider outputs 1 × 1 matrices.) can show confidence interval :
code: library(stats) library(tidyverse) n <- 1000 rate <- 1 x <- tibble(x=stats::rexp(n,rate)) print(x) #> # A tibble: 1,000 × 1 #>         x #>     <dbl> #>  1 0.0262 #>  2 1.34   #>  3 0.296  #>  4 2.30   #>  5 0.490  #>  6 1.60   #>  7 0.659  #>  8 1.45   #>  9 1.08   #> 10 0.520  #> # … with 990 more rows library(ggplot2) ggplot(x, aes(x=x)) + geom_histogram(aes(y=..density..),alpha=.2) +     xlim(0,6) +      geom_function(fun=dexp) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin). #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_bar). library(algebraic.mle) #>  #> Attaching package: 'algebraic.mle' #> The following object is masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     nobs rate.hat <- mle_exp(x$x) summary(rate.hat) #> Maximum likelihood estimator, of type mle_exp , #> is normally distributed with mean #> [1] 0.9775105 #> and variance-covariance #>              [,1] #> [1,] 0.0009555267 #> --- #> The asymptotic mean squared error 0.0009555267  #> The asymptotic 95% confidence interval is #>       2.5 %   97.5 % #> 1 0.9266654 1.028356 #> The log-likelihood is -1022.746  #> The AIC is 2047.493 point(rate.hat) #> [1] 0.9775105 fisher_info(rate.hat) #>          [,1] #> [1,] 1046.543 vcov(rate.hat) #>              [,1] #> [1,] 0.0009555267 confint(rate.hat) #>       2.5 %   97.5 % #> 1 0.9266654 1.028356

title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: general, estimate sampling distribution, generate B = 10000 samples (size 1000) corresponding estimators, θ̂(1), …, θ̂(B). Normally, B samples, , gather B samples one sample (used weighted MLE), contain (Fisher) information θ. However, nice property MLEs , asymptotically, converge normal distribution mean given true parameter, case λ, variance-covariance given inverse Fisher information matrix, .e., λ̂ ∼ N(λ,−1(λ)) Fisher information matrix, case (λ) = n/λ2. observe empirical sampling distribution θ̂ overlaid theoretical asymptotic distribution :  know λ, may estimate sample, thus may approximate sampling distribution λ̂ N(λ̂,−1(λ̂)). Since giving one sample, provide B estimates λ. However, can sample approximation asymptotic distribution λ̂ : visually compare two MLE samples, data0 data1, :  Due sampling error, see approximation, estimate asymptotic sampling distribution N(λ̂,λ̂/n1/2), shifted left sample true distribution, appear quite similar otherwise.
code: B <- 1000 data0 <- numeric(length=B) for (i in 1:B) {     x <- stats::rexp(n,rate)     data0[i] <- point(mle_exp(x)) } ggplot(tibble(rate.hat=data0), aes(x=rate.hat)) +     geom_histogram(aes(y=..density..),alpha=.3,bins=50) +     geom_function(fun=function(x) { dnorm(x,mean=rate,sd=rate/sqrt(n)) }) data1 <- sampler(rate.hat)(B) data <- data.frame(values=c(data0,data1), group=c(rep("empirical",B),rep("approximation",B)))  ggplot(data,aes(x=values,fill=group)) +     geom_histogram(aes(y=..density..),position="identity", alpha=0.2, bins=50)

title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: interesting property MLE λ̂ MLE g(λ) given g(λ̂). method fn_distr applied mle objects takes function mle simulation sample size computes MLE, .e., returns object type fn_mle, also MLE asymptotic sampling distribution.

title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: Suppose interested g(λ) = 2λ: Let’s compare simulation actual distribution. know MLE λ̂ ∼ N(λ,λ2/n). seek transformation g(λ̂) taht expectation 2λ, .e., g(λ) = 2λ. , var (g(λ̂)) = 4λ2/n. Letting λ = 1, see g(λ̂) ∼ N(2λ,4λ2/n). simulate drawing n = 1000 observations
code: g <- function(lambda) 2*lambda  g.hat <- fn_distr(rate.hat,g) point(g.hat) #> [1] 1.955021 vcov(g.hat) #>            [,1] #> [1,] 0.00384802 confint(g.hat) #>      2.5 %   97.5 % #> 1 1.852987 2.057055 data4 <- rnorm(1000,2,2/sqrt(1000)) mean(data4) #> [1] 2.005012 var(data4) #> [1] 0.003933318

what: Weighted MLE: a weighted sum of maximum likelihood estimators
title: Algebraic maximum likelihood estimators
text: Since variance-covariance MLE inversely proportional Fisher information MLE defined respect , can combine multiple MLEs θ, may defined respect different kind sample, arrive MLE incorporates Fisher information samples. Consider k mutually independent MLE estimators parameter θ, θ̂1, …, θ̂k, θ̂j ∼ N(θ,Ij−1(θ)). , maximum likelihood estimator θ incorporates data θ̂1, …, θ̂k given inverse-variance weighted mean, θ̂ = (∑Ij(θ))−1(∑Ij(θ)θj). evaluate performance estimator, generate sample N = 1000 EXP (λ=1). compute MLE observed sample, denoted θ. divide observed sample r = 5 sub-samples, size N/r = 100, compute MLE sub-sampled, denoted θ(1), …, θ(r). Finally, come MLEs weighted MLE, denoted θw. see θ̂ θ̂w model approximately sampling distribution θ.
code: N <- 1000 r <- 5 data3 <- rexp(N) data3.mat <- matrix(data3,nrow=r) mles <- list(length=r) for (i in 1:r)     mles[[i]] <- mle_exp(data3.mat[i,])  mle.wt <- mle_weighted(mles) summary(mle.wt) #> Maximum likelihood estimator, of type mle_weighted , #> is normally distributed with mean #>          [,1] #> [1,] 1.004032 #> and variance-covariance #>             [,1] #> [1,] 0.001013711 #> --- #> The asymptotic mean squared error 0.001013711  #> The asymptotic 95% confidence interval is #>       2.5 %   97.5 % #> 1 0.9516617 1.056402 #> The log-likelihood is -987.5218  #> The AIC is 1977.044  mle.tot <- mle_exp(data3) summary(mle.tot) #> Maximum likelihood estimator, of type mle_exp , #> is normally distributed with mean #> [1] 1.00964 #> and variance-covariance #>             [,1] #> [1,] 0.001019373 #> --- #> The asymptotic mean squared error 0.001019373  #> The asymptotic 95% confidence interval is #>      2.5 %   97.5 % #> 1 0.957124 1.062157 #> The log-likelihood is -990.4059  #> The AIC is 1982.812

what: Computes the MSE of an MLE — mle_mse
title: Computes the MSE of an MLE — mle_mse
text: MSE estimator theta.hat defined     mse(theta.hat) = E[(theta.hat-theta)^2] = vcov(theta.hat) + (bias(theta.hat))^2. bias = E(theta.hat-theta), .e., MSE depends theta. definition MSE theta.hat given difference $$     f(theta.hat) $$

what:
Accepts a list of mle objects for some parameter, say theta,
and combines them into a single estimator mle_weighted — mle_weighted
title:

and combines them into a single estimator mle_weighted — mle_weighted
text: combines mle objects adding together, weighted inverse respective variance-covariance matrix. Intuitively, higher variance, less weight mle given summation.

title:
Accepts a list of mle objects for some parameter, say theta,
and combines them into a single estimator mle_weighted — mle_weighted
code: data1 <- rexp(100,2) data2 <- rexp(200,2) mle1 <- mle_exp(data1) cat(point(mle1)) #> 2.150373 mle2 <- mle_exp(data2) cat(point(mle2)) #> 2.061949 mle.wt <- mle_weighted(list(mle1,mle2)) summary(mle.wt) #> Maximum likelihood estimator, of type mle_weighted , #> is normally distributed with mean #>          [,1] #> [1,] 2.089797 #> and variance-covariance #>            [,1] #> [1,] 0.01456313 #> --- #> The asymptotic mean squared error 0.01456313  #> The asymptotic 95% confidence interval is #>    2.5 %   97.5 % #> 1 1.8913 2.288294 #> The log-likelihood is -78.70557  #> The AIC is 159.4111  mle <- mle_exp(c(data1,data2)) point(mle) #> [1] 2.090604 aic(mle) #> [1] 159.5281 loglike(mle) #> [1] -78.76407
